intro: Chavica grandis, commonly known as the Indian chervil or chervil de Inde, is a flowering plant native to southern and eastern Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and thrives in temperate climates. Its seeds are used in traditional medicine for their aromatic and anti-inflammatory properties. The plant is also cultivated as a ornamental due to its delicate appearance and fragrance.
